M.G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to M.G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $25,000 and the cause of action sounds in tort.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue in Berkshire County is proper under M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the Defendant resides and the events giving rise to this claim occurred within this county.

*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners owe a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain their property and any artificial or natural conditions thereon so as to prevent foreseeable harm to others (see *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973); *Schofield v. Merrill*, 386 Mass. 244 (1982)).
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard is the seminal Massachusetts case abolishing the common‑law distinction between invitees and licensees and imposing a general duty of reasonable care owed by property occupiers to lawful entrants. Although the excerpt provided is only a concurrence by Justice Kaplan and focuses on the treatment of trespassers, the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707 explicitly adopts a general reasonable‑care standard related to conditions on land, which aligns with the proposition. Because we are given only a concurring passage and not the key majority language, confidence is medium rather than high.
*Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707.relevant_excerpt:
[From the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 707 (not in the excerpt provided):]
"We hold that a landowner must act as a reasonable person in maintaining his property in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk."

*Schofield v. Merrill*, 386 Mass. 244 (1.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, property owners owe a duty to exercise reasonable care to maintain their property and any artificial or natural conditions thereon so as to prevent foreseeable harm to others (see *Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973); *Schofield v. Merrill*, 386 Mass. 244 (1982)).
*Schofield v. Merrill*, 386 Mass. 244 (1.support_reasoning: Schofield reaffirms the traditional Massachusetts rule that landowners owe no duty of reasonable care to adult trespassers, subject only to narrow exceptions (helplessly trapped trespassers and certain child trespassers). The opinion explicitly preserves Mounsey’s extension of a reasonable-care duty only to “lawful visitors” and expressly refuses to extend a general duty of reasonable care to all entrants or to all “artificial or natural conditions” vis‑à‑vis adult trespassers. Thus, it does not stand for the broad proposition that owners owe a duty of reasonable care to prevent foreseeable harm to “others” generally; instead, it limits that duty with respect to adult trespassers.
*Schofield v. Merrill*, 386 Mass. 244 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The traditional rule in this Commonwealth is that a trespasser is entitled to no greater duty of care from one with a right of control over land (typically the landowner) than that he refrain from wilful, wanton or reckless disregard for the trespasser’s safety.… In Mounsey, we held that the standard of due care applied to all lawful entrants. Id. at 703, 706-707. We expressly excluded trespassers from this rule. Id. at 707 n.7.… We conclude that the rule should be retained, and we affirm the judgment of the Superior Court.”

*Gerhardt v. Burris*, 346 Mass. 629 (196.proposition: The duty of reasonable care extends to maintaining trees and limbs adjacent to public sidewalks to prevent injury to passersby (see *Gerhardt v. Burris*, 346 Mass. 629 (1964); *Gallagher v. City of Worcester*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 946 (1983)).
*Gerhardt v. Burris*, 346 Mass. 629 (196.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a fraudulent conveyance of funds from a debtor to her father to hinder a creditor and whether the creditor can reach those assets or impose liability on the father’s estate. It does not involve premises liability, trees, sidewalks, or any duty of reasonable care toward passersby. The case is purely about creditor–debtor rights and fraudulent transfers, so it does not support the stated proposition about maintaining trees adjacent to public sidewalks.
*Gerhardt v. Burris*, 346 Mass. 629 (196.relevant_excerpt: We assume that the transfer to Maloof could have been set aside while it remained in effect as a conveyance made with actual intent to defraud Modin. See G. L. (Ter. Ed.) c. 109A, §§ 7, 9, 10; David v. Zilah, 325 Mass. 252, 256; Virta v. Mackey, 343 Mass. 286, 290-291. … Before this bill was brought, however, and before Modin’s claim was reduced to judgment, the property transferred by Hanron to Maloof was returned.

*Gallagher v. City of Worcester*, 16 Mas.raw_text: *Gallagher v. City of Worcester*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 946 (1983)
*Gallagher v. City of Worcester*, 16 Mas.proposition: The duty of reasonable care extends to maintaining trees and limbs adjacent to public sidewalks to prevent injury to passersby (see *Gerhardt v. Burris*, 346 Mass. 629 (1964); *Gallagher v. City of Worcester*, 16 Mass. App. Ct. 946 (1983)).
*Gallagher v. City of Worcester*, 16 Mas.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns the trial court’s jurisdiction under Mass. R. Crim. P. 29(a) to revise and revoke criminal sentences and whether the reduction of sentences was an abuse of discretion. It does not address premises liability, sidewalks, trees, or any duty of care to passersby. The proposition about maintaining trees adjacent to public sidewalks is unrelated to the issues or holding in this case, so the citation is inaccurate for that purpose.
*Gallagher v. City of Worcester*, 16 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The only issue presented on this appeal by the Commonwealth is whether the Superior Court judge had jurisdiction to reduce the minimum terms of certain of the defendant’s sentences, imposed after the defendant’s guilty pleas… 2. There was no abuse of discretion or error of law in the reduction of the sentences.”

*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.proposition: Defendant’s inaction constitutes a breach of the standard of care recognized in Massachusetts tort law (see *Restatement (Second) of Torts* § 363; *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980); *Janosky v. Preferred Mutual Ins. Co.*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 518 (1987)).
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a Massachusetts landlord owes a duty of reasonable care in negligence to tenants’ guests regarding defects on the demised premises and that negligent failure (i.e., inaction) to repair a known dangerous condition breaches that duty. The court reverses JNOV and orders reinstatement of the jury’s negligence verdict against the landlord, explicitly framing the issue as whether the landlord’s nonfeasance—failure to repair a known dangerous porch railing—constitutes actionable negligence under Massachusetts tort law. This directly supports the proposition that such inaction can amount to a breach of the standard of care.
*Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980.relevant_excerpt: “Today, we do away with the ancient law that bars a tenant’s guest from recovering compensation from a landlord for injuries caused by negligent maintenance of areas rented to the tenant… Henceforth, landlords as other persons must exercise reasonable care not to subject others to an unreasonable risk of harm… A landlord must act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances… In particular, a landlord should not be liable in negligence unless he knew or reasonably should have known of the defect and had a reasonable opportunity to repair it.”

*Janosky v. Preferred Mutual Ins. Co.*,.raw_text: *Janosky v. Preferred Mutual Ins. Co.*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 518 (1987)
*Janosky v. Preferred Mutual Ins. Co.*,.proposition: Defendant’s inaction constitutes a breach of the standard of care recognized in Massachusetts tort law (see *Restatement (Second) of Torts* § 363; *Young v. Garwacki*, 380 Mass. 162 (1980); *Janosky v. Preferred Mutual Ins. Co.*, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 518 (1987)).
*Janosky v. Preferred Mutual Ins. Co.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a domestic relations/contract interpretation case about enforcing a separation agreement to pay for college education beyond age twenty‑one and the Probate Court’s jurisdiction under G.L. c. 208, §§ 1A and 28. It does not discuss negligence, tort duties, the Restatement (Second) of Torts § 363, or any standard of care, nor does it characterize any party’s inaction as a tortious breach of a duty of care. Using Janosky as authority for a Massachusetts tort-law standard of care is therefore inaccurate.
*Janosky v. Preferred Mutual Ins. Co.*,.relevant_excerpt: “We are of opinion that there is a significant difference between a provision for education rendered by a judge pursuant to § 28 following litigation, and a judgment or order which incorporates and requires compliance with the provisions of a bargained-for agreement.… But where the parties have, through mutual agreement, made provision for their children past age twenty-one, and desire that the agreement (after approval by the judge), be incorporated in the judgment, we think the incorporated agreement may be enforced by means of a contempt proceeding.”

*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.proposition: The harm to Plaintiff was a foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence, satisfying the element of causation (see *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101 (1978); *Sullivan v. O’Connor*, 363 Mass. 579 (1973)).
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses foreseeability and causation where a third party’s wrongful conduct intervenes. The court applies the general rule that an intervening act does not break the chain of causation if it was foreseeable, and expressly holds that the seaman’s operation of the unsecured forklift was a foreseeable result of the Authority’s negligence and that a jury could find plaintiff’s injury was caused by that negligent act. This directly supports the proposition that the harm was a foreseeable result of defendant’s negligence, satisfying causation.
*Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*,.relevant_excerpt: “Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… It was thus reasonably foreseeable that the forklift, when left unsecured with the keys in the ignition… would be operated by unauthorized persons, including inebriated seamen… It was also reasonably foreseeable… that unauthorized operation would likely cause harm to persons known to pass through the area… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

*Sullivan v. O\u2019Connor*, 363 Mass. 5.proposition: The harm to Plaintiff was a foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence, satisfying the element of causation (see *Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.*, 376 Mass. 101 (1978); *Sullivan v. O’Connor*, 363 Mass. 579 (1973)).
*Sullivan v. O\u2019Connor*, 363 Mass. 5.support_reasoning: The opinion is a contract-damages case, not a negligence case. The court’s discussion of “proximately and foreseeably” flowing damages is about the scope of contract damages (expectation vs. reliance), not about tort causation or whether the harm was a foreseeable result of negligent conduct. The jury expressly found no negligence, so the case cannot be authority that Plaintiff’s harm was a foreseeable result of Defendant’s negligence for purposes of satisfying tort causation.
*Sullivan v. O\u2019Connor*, 363 Mass. 5.relevant_excerpt: “Second, she could recover the damages flowing directly, naturally, proximately, and foreseeably from the defendant’s breach of promise. These would comprehend damages for any disfigurement of the plaintiff’s nose … Also consequent upon the defendant’s breach, and compensable, were the pain and suffering involved in the third operation…” (363 Mass. at 580–581).

*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540 (.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries, including physical pain, medical expenses, lost wages, and emotional distress, were directly and proximately caused by Defendant’s breach (see *Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540 (1982)).
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540 (.support_reasoning: The opinion in Payton does not discuss or decide issues of specific causation of a plaintiff’s physical pain, medical expenses, lost wages, or emotional distress by a defendant’s breach in the way the proposition suggests. Instead, it addresses whether Massachusetts recognizes a cause of action for negligent infliction of emotional distress without physical injury, prenatal injury claims, wrongful‑life–type barring of recovery, and market‑share liability in DES cases. It does not set out or apply a rule that a plaintiff’s enumerated injuries were directly and proximately caused by a defendant’s breach, so it does not support the cited proposition.
*Payton v. Abbott Labs*, 386 Mass. 540 (.relevant_excerpt: "We note initially that neither the issue of negligence nor that of causation is before us. The certified question assumes both that the defendants were negligent, and that their negligence caused the plaintiffs' emotional distress."

*Donahue v. Stephens*, 342 Mass. 89 (196.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for her personal injuries, economic losses, and pain and suffering (see *Donahue v. Stephens*, 342 Mass. 89 (1961); M.G.L. c. 231, §§ 85, 85A).
*Donahue v. Stephens*, 342 Mass. 89 (196.support_reasoning: The case involves tort actions seeking recovery solely for property damage to a house and furnishings, not for personal injuries, economic losses, or pain and suffering. The opinion discusses negligence, causation, and vendor/contractor liability, and ultimately holds that the plaintiffs cannot recover at all; it does not address the scope of recoverable personal injury damages or endorse recovery for pain and suffering. Citing this case as authority for the types of damages recoverable by a personal injury plaintiff is therefore inaccurate.
*Donahue v. Stephens*, 342 Mass. 89 (196.relevant_excerpt: "These are two actions of tort for negligence in which the plaintiffs seek recovery for property damage to their house and furnishings against I. Whitman Stephens, the builder, and Timothy F. Sweeney, a heating subcontractor... In the Stephens case the order of the Appellate Division dismissing the report is reversed, the finding for the plaintiffs is vacated, and judgment is to be entered for the defendant. In the Sweeney case the order of the Appellate Division... ordering judgment to be entered for the defendant is affirmed."

M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7\u00a7 85, 85A.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for her personal injuries, economic losses, and pain and suffering (see *Donahue v. Stephens*, 342 Mass. 89 (1961); M.G.L. c. 231, §§ 85, 85A).

M.G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award pre- and post-judgment interest pursuant to M.G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
